data.title: Jean Lanne. "Roland of the French Army"
data.meta_description: Marshal Lann: "Davout's mind, Ney's courage and Murat's beauty." The path from private to marshal, wars in Spain and Italy Jean-Charles Perrin. Jean Lannes, duc de Montebello, marechal de France In this portrait, painted between 1805-1810. Lann is depicted in the uniform of a hussar colonel Often
data.text:
Jean-Charles Perrin. Jean Lannes, duc de Montebello, marechal de France. This portrait, painted between 1805-1810, depicts Lannes in the uniform of a hussar colonel

It is often argued that people who knew Napoleon well saw tears in his eyes only twice: upon the news of the death of General Louis Deset, whose timely return of the division made it possible to win the Battle of Marengo, and upon visiting the mortally wounded Marshal Jean Lannes in a field hospital.

According to researchers, Lannes was one of those Napoleon's marshals who had an independent talent for leadership and could win in the absence of Bonaparte.

In addition, Jean Lannes possessed incredible charisma, and his contemporaries called him Roland, Achilles and Ajax of the French army. They also said that this marshal had Davout's mind, Ney's courage and Murat's beauty.

F. Gerard. Portrait of Lannes, Army Museum, Paris

You can also add "Augereau's rudeness". With this Marshal Lanna had in common a true passion for the crudest and dirtiest curses. Until the end of his life, even to Napoleon, Lannes turned to "you", which was very displeasing to the emperor, who wrote:

“This devil Lann has all the qualities of an outstanding commander, but he will never be the first, because he cannot control his character; this constant quarrelsomeness with his junior officers is a huge disadvantage for the commander. "

And also:

"In anger, Lann did not allow anyone to insert a word, and in this state he was dangerous to the interlocutor."

But, admittedly, Lann was an extremely capable and incredibly brave general. This forced Napoleon to put up with his shortcomings:

"Lann in battle shows more courage than reason, but each time the mind wakes up in him and restores balance."

And more:

“I found him as a pygmy and lost him as a giant. Lann was an extraordinary courage. Remaining completely calm in the fire, he possessed a remarkable eye, and not a single chance that could be used escaped him. "

Another feature of Lann was his extreme dislike for the British. The English historian R.F. Delderfield wrote:

"Jean Lannes could be tolerant of Austrians, Prussians, Russians and even Italians, but only a dead Englishman could be good for him."

Childhood and adolescence of Jean Lanne

The future marshal was the same age as Bonaparte and Ney. He was born on April 10, 1769 in the small Gascon town of Lectour (department of Gers), located near the Iberian Peninsula.

Monument to Lann in his hometown - Lectura

The family in which the future marshal was born could not be called very prosperous. But she owned a land plot, most of which was leased, so it would be wrong to consider her very poor. Our hero was the fourth child and the second of four sons, and two boys were baptized with the name Bernard, the other two - Jean (this was a family tradition). The family was large (8 children), and there was not enough money from the rent. And therefore, of these boys, only the elder Bernard, who studied at the seminary, received an education. It was he who taught to read, write and count his younger brother, who was destined to become a marshal. And the parents did not pin particular hopes on Jean and therefore did not send him to study, having sent him to the local dyer as an apprentice. The young man did not like the job, and at the first opportunity he enlisted in the royal army. This attempt at military service was unsuccessful: Lann quarreled with a colleague, it came to a duel, in which he was wounded. Was dismissed. After recovering, I had to return to my previous job, but the master greeted him very coldly. And once I advised him:

"Go back to the army, maybe you can become a captain."

The master did not even suspect how good and practical his advice would turn out to be: Lann would receive his first general rank at the age of 27, he would become a divisional general at 30, a marshal at 35, and a duke at 38.

The beginning of service in the army of Republican France

Lannes made his second attempt to become a military man after the start of the revolution, joining the Second Volunteer Battalion of the Gers department in June 1792. The volunteers were trained at the Miral training camp near Toulouse, which was led by General Marbeau the Elder. His unbearable nature did not stop Lann from studying hard and attracting the attention of teachers. His immediate superior, Lieutenant Pose, describes his student as follows:

"The young Gascon is very mobile, quick-witted, cheerful, without upbringing and education, but striving for knowledge."

Since Lann already had experience in military service, after 2 weeks he was appointed a sergeant, and then the soldiers elected him to the post of junior lieutenant.

Pauline Guerin. Jean lannes en 1792, en uniforme de sous-lieutenant du 2e bataillon des volontaires du Gerspar (1835), Versailles

Remembering the first unsuccessful duel, Lann began to actively practice fencing, taking lessons from several teachers at once. As an apprentice, he proved to be very capable, quickly gaining a reputation as an excellent swordsman.

During the war with Spain, the Lanna battalion became part of the East Pyrenean army. Lann managed to distinguish himself in the first battle at the Saint Lauren-en-Cerdan Pass, which took place on May 17, 1793. Suddenly attacked by the Spaniards, Lannes's colleagues almost fled from the battlefield, but the Gascon managed to stop them and even organized a successful counterattack.

On September 25, 1793, Lannes was promoted to lieutenant and became company commander. Then, less than a month later (October 21), he became captain and battalion commander. In this rank, he received his first wound.

How many times Lann was wounded, no one knows for sure. Various authors count from 10 to 20 injuries in 17 years. It is believed that of the other marshals of Napoleon, only Oudinot had more wounds (from 19 to 34, according to various sources), who, by the way, was nicknamed the "colander" by the soldiers.

Without really finishing his treatment, Lannes returned to the army, where he soon distinguished himself in the battle of Villelong: at the head of 500 soldiers, he knocked out the Spaniards from a well-fortified position, capturing 19 artillery pieces and 5 thousand pairs of boots (it was thanks to the capture of boots that he then became incredibly popular in the army ).

The command also noted the brave Gascon: on December 25, 1793, he received the rank of lieutenant colonel and was appointed brigade commander.

Lann received a wound in the field healed poorly, and therefore he was sent for treatment to Perpignan. In this city, he met the daughter of a local banker - Poletta Merik. On March 19, 1798, she became the wife of a young general. This marriage broke up after Paulette gave birth to a child, while Lann was in Egypt and could not be a father in any way.

But before that there was still a war in Spain under the command of General Perignon. And then - transfer to the Italian army, where he became the commander of the 105th semi-brigade as part of the Augereau division and took part in the Battle of Loano.

Acquaintance with Bonaparte

After the Thermidorian coup, Lann, known for his pro-Jacobin views, (by that time already a colonel) was removed from office. The formal reason was the lack of military education. It is difficult to say how his fate would have developed in the future if Bonaparte, who needed decisive people to suppress the royalist rebellion in October 1795, had not seen the reports of the former commanders Lannes - Augereau and Scherer, which contained high assessments of his actions.

He also remembered Lanna when he set out on his first Italian campaign. The disgraced colonel was offered a low position of battalion commander. Lann agreed and was right. After successful operations in the battles of Millesimo (April 13, 1796) and Dego (April 14-15, 1796), he was appointed commander of a semi-brigade, which was one of the first to cross the Po River and distinguished itself at the Battle of Fombio (May 5, 1796). ). After the Battle of Lodi (May 10), Napoleon formed a select squad to guard the army headquarters. Lann became its commander.

At the same time, he takes part in the battle of Bassano (September 8, 1796) and in the same month receives the rank of brigadier general for his actions during the assault on Pavia. Then Lann replaces the commander of one of the brigades, which, under his leadership, captured one of the forts of Mantua. And he was seriously wounded in the battle at Governo. Already in November 1796, Lannes, who was not healed, took part in the battle at Arcole, where he was again wounded, covering Bonaparte. He did not leave the army and the very next day he received a new wound - on the Arkolsky bridge. This time they carry him away on a stretcher. Everything lived on Lannes, "like a cat", and already in January 1797 he took part in the battle of Rivoli.

Lannes statue, Louvre facade, Rue de Rivoli

Then, in February 1797, he takes part in the campaign against Rome and in the battle of the Senino River.

Finally, Lannes finds himself in the Eastern (Egyptian) army of Bonaparte. He begins his service in it as a commander of a semi-brigade (in July 1798 he fights in the battles of Alexandria and Cairo). During the Syrian campaign (February-June 1799), he already commanded a division. He received further injuries during the siege of the fortress of Saint-Jean-d'Acr and in the battle of Aboukir. Leaves Egypt together with Bonaparte on August 23, 1799 - already with the rank of divisional general.

After the coup of the 18th Brumaire (November 9, 1799), Lannes was appointed commander of the Consular Guard.

Marbeau the Younger describes him then:

“Lann was of medium height and very well built; the face was pleasant and expressive; the eyes are small, but expressing a lively mind; character is good when he restrained himself, but at times he was carried away; ambitious, unusually active and courageous in all circumstances. "

And he clarifies that after a wound in the neck, received during the siege of Saint-Jean-d'Acr, the head of this general "was tilted to the right».

There is also a description of Lannes in the memoirs of Laura d'Abrantes:

“This young general was five feet and five or six inches (that is, 165-167 cm), slender, elegant; the legs and arms are pretty pretty. The face was not beautiful, but it was expressive, and when his voice expressed one of the military thoughts in those situations thanks to which he was named Roland of the army, his eyes threw lightning. He had a reputation for being brave that overshadowed all others. "

In addition, many describe him as an elegant and tidy person dressed "with a needle". Moreover, Lann watched his clothes and appearance not only in peacetime, but also during hostilities, claiming that

"On the battlefield, in the eyes of the soldiers, their commanders should look as if they were going to a wedding."

At this time, he just divorced his first wife - and unexpectedly became carried away by Bonaparte's sister, Caroline. This girl preferred Joachim Murat. And Lanne's wife was Louise Antoinette Scholastica de Göhenek, who bore him 5 children. The wedding took place on September 16, 1800.

Marguerite Gerard. Duchesse de Montebello with Her Children 1814

Lannes in Bonaparte's Second Italian Campaign

During the Second Italian Campaign of Napoleon, on June 9, 1800, the vanguard units of Lanna at Montebello, before the arrival of reinforcements, successfully repelled the attacks of the Austrian General Ott, which were three times superior to them. Lannes later became Duke of Montebello.

For heroism in the battle of Marengo (June 14, 1800), he was awarded a saber. In addition, according to the widespread version, it was then that Napoleon called Lann "Roland of the army."

Disgraced General Lann

However, after returning to Paris, relations between the First Consul and the commander of his guard began to deteriorate steadily. Bonaparte was no longer the former army commander, but the leader of a powerful state. He was now annoyed by Lann's familiarity, who still thought it possible to address him as "you." And then even Napoleon's relatives did not allow themselves this. Lannes, in turn, almost openly accused Bonaparte of betraying republican ideals. Suddenly, he found himself at the head of a whole circle of opposition-minded generals and senior officers. It all ended with the accusation (quite fair) of embezzlement of state funds, which was brought against Lann by the auditing Bessières (since then Lann and Bessières have become mortal enemies). The shortfall was covered from his own funds by the former commander of Lanna André Augereau, Lann was removed from office and sent as ambassador to Portugal. The position of the commander of the guard was abolished altogether: Bessières began to command the guards cavalry, Davout for the grenadiers, Soult for the light infantry, and Mortier for the artillery. Since 1804, each of them began to be called the Colonel-General of the Guard.

Lann's return

The diplomatic career of the rude Lanna did not work as expected. In Lisbon, he behaved extremely cocky and arrogant. Very soon, all the Portuguese who communicated with the French ambassador simply hated him, and in 1803 Napoleon was forced to recall Lannes to Paris. Here the disgraced general was out of work for some time. However, soon Napoleon made Lann understand that service was still possible for him. The awarding of the newly established Order of the Legion of Honor became such a sign. And after the coronation, Napoleon introduced the retired general to the number of marshals of France. Finally, in August 1805, Lannes was appointed commander of the V corps of the Grand Army. In its composition, for the first time, he will have to engage in battle with Russian troops. We will talk about this and much more in the next article.

Ryzhov V.A.
